entry.et: Middle English tour, tor, from Old English torr & Anglo-French tur, tour, both from Latin turris, from Greek tyrris, tyrsis

def.dt: :a building or structure typically higher than its diameter and high relative to its surroundings that may stand apart (as a campanile) or be attached (as a church belfry) to a larger structure and that may be fully walled in or of skeleton framework (as an observation or transmission tower)
:one that provides support or protection :bulwark a tower of strength
:a personal computer case that stands in an upright position
:to reach or rise to a great height
:to exhibit superior qualities :surpass her intellect towered over the others'
:a tall building (as a high-rise apartment building)
borough of E Greater London, England pop 153,500
:a tower that supports or shelters a bell
:a raised structure on the deck of a submarine used especially formerly for navigation and attack direction
:a structure over which circulated water is trickled to reduce its temperature by partial evaporation
:a tower (as in a forest) from which a watch for fires is maintained
